title: How to tell a child, as a teacher, that they have an odor - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, this is from someone who was that kid - absolutely DON'T go to the parents about it. Either they're unaware of the problem and so could then have the problem themselves and you'll only offend them and, depending on the intelligence of the parents - bring a world of trouble down on the kid and yourself. Or they could be like my parents - aware of this issue and using it to keep the kid down. I was not allowed to practice normal hygiene because my mother said only “sluts who were trying to get boys attention behaved like that.” i was allowed daily showers but that wasn't enough, we lived in a subtropical climate. A parent doing similar will just punish the kid for exposing their abuse. (Like, you're supposed to stink but not around anyone who could call out your parents!?) I was an adult before someone told me, bluntly and disgustedly and I was devastated. Looking back, people had tried to hint to me before, but I didn't understand - having been trained to not notice the smell as different. So please DO let the child know that you've noticed an odor, they might not be too upset, but if they're sensitive like I was they'll be crushed. So just accept that, and that they're going to hate you for this wound for a bit, but better that now then letting them go on in that state. They'll be grateful one day and will probably never forget you. Just be as kind as you can and make sure they know HEAPS of kids go through this - dont call it a “problem” (exaggerate here, because you dont want defences going up which will make them not listen to the hygeine advice) and then straight away have the hygiene advice ready. Say lots of people dont get taught this at home, it's quite common. And then just explain everything quickly - regular bathing, hair washing, teeth brushing, deodorant etc. Be very basic, like say “generally the advice is to shower daily, put deodorant on every day, wash hair every 2–3 days and brush teeth at least twice a day” or whatever your local customs are, make it a quick list so they absorb the information without lingering too long on what they don't know and thus reinforcing the shame. Make sure they know that not everyone knows this - that they're not strange. You could have a small bag of supplies ready, that could be a huge help, but they might not be able to bring it home if their parents are like mine. If parents like that smell a clean fragrance on their child they could inflict further punishment and take it off them. If they say they're not allowed to use that much water (not sure where you're from, and local water access/costs) maybe have some alternatives to showering in mind, like having a “bits-n-pits” wash in the sink. Lol I'm not sure what you're allowed to say in that regard. Also be prepared that the parents may still come after you, be ready to stand your ground and explain why its important for their child to know this stuff. If they dont practice it at home, they'll be all sorts of furious at your “interference” and “criticism”. Get your principal/another teacher to have your back Thank you for wanting to do this for the child - you are doing a really kind thing. I am now so paranoid about odors of any kind and have never got over the humiliation and deep down feeling of being nothing more than trash. You could be preventing this!

This is always a sensitive topic…more so if the child is a teen where appearance and ‘self-presentation' is at the top of the social/peer critique list. For the record, it may NOT be a case of the child being neglected or the child/parents not understanding proper hygiene. Those cases tend to be fairly evident: dirty clothes, re-worn clothes, dirty hair and nails, etc… For many children, especially those starting or in puberty, it can actually be a medical, hormonal or chemical balance issue. This is the case with our 15 year old daughter. The year before she entered puberty, we noticed she seemed to have unusually strong body odor. She showers every day…sometimes twice a day. She always has clean clothes and uses deodorant, but she would still start to have a noticeable body odor a few hours later. Although no one at her middle school ever said anything to her or us, we knew they had to notice. I would pick her up after school and the minute she got in the car I would need to roll the windows down it was so strong! We gently tried EVERY remedy available to us at home. We made sure she was washing properly and tried various combinations of deodorants, body washes, natural/holistic remedies…anything we researched, we tried, but nothing really helped. As she approached entering high school, where peer critique and bullying is even worse and boys/dating would enter the picture, we were really worried for her. High school boys (and girls!) can be extremely cruel, both intentionally AND unintentionally. She is a special needs child, extremely sensitive and suffers from anxiety. Although her body is that of a normal 15 year old young woman, her mind is a few years behind. She is used to people being kind to her and she's a beautiful girl, so she garners a lot of attention from boys. Again, we were really worried about what would happen when she entered high school. We consulted her pediatrician and he immediately set us up with an endocrinologist. It turns out that like myself, she suffers from polycystic ovarian syndrome. Her hormone levels, particularly her testosterone levels (yes…women have it, too!), were way out of balance. Her body was producing too much of some hormones and not enough of others. There are medications, like some birth control pills, that help with that. Many medications have purposes beyond their advertised one and while some may disapprove of putting their daughters on birth control (though I don't know why!), this was a medicine that could help her balance her hormones and in turn, help the body odor problem. So we tried it and it worked! It didn't ‘cure' the odor problem completely, but it helped enough that in combination with careful hygiene, she could make it through a hot day of school without it being too noticeable. My point here is that the child you are trying to help may have a medical issue, not a hygiene or family neglect issue. But how do you approach the family directly? As others have written, that can be very tricky. I would start by NOT singling out the child. Get permission to send home a letter to ALL the children's parents. Explain gently that with it being summertime and with so many people closed up in a room, there have been some issues with strong odors. Ask that each parent discuss proper hygiene with their child, as sometimes children need reminders. Then offer to be of assistance if anyone has concerns for their child or needs help. If possible and guidelines allow for it, require the letter to be signed and returned so that you know the specific child you are trying to help has indeed given the letter to their parents. Perhaps the child's parents simply aren't aware of what is going on because they are use to how their child smells. For those that ARE aware, perhaps this will motivate them to help their child, so they as parents, aren't singled out for what most would consider an embarrassing situation. Hopefully this first step will do the trick. If not, my second step would be to privately talk to the child. If it's a case of the family not being able to afford soap or deodorant, maybe you or the school can help by giving out small bags of essential hygiene products. Then the child could take it home and say ‘hey…they were giving these out to everyone today’ and the parents wouldn't feel like they were being singled out for charity or pitied. However, the trickiest position you might find yourself in is if the parents (for whatever reason) don't want their child to change the current situation. At that point, perhaps a one on one meeting with you and a guidance counselor or school nurse would be necessary. The bottom line is this problem does need to be addressed for the child's sake. The older he/she gets, the worse the bullying and picking on will get and those situations almost always end badly for the poor child. You will also have to accept that nothing you try may help. If the parents aren't willing to parent properly and help their child, you may not get anywhere. Kudos to you for stepping up and trying!! I deeply admire teachers who truly care for their students beyond the lesson plan. Good luck!!

So, I can tell you as a mental health professional that this has been one of the most challenging subjects with which to approach someone. There are many ways to do it and the best way depends a great deal on many factors; the age & gender of the child, the nature and strength of your relationship with the child, how often you have observed the odor and your sense about the source of it. Breath, foot and armpits that are not fresh can be a lil less daunting than odor emanating from the middle grounds. One approach for a child 8 or older is to give them a book on personal hygiene. There are many that are written for children’s reading levels. American Girl has a nice one. I’ve added a pic of it below. You can take the child aside and say something like “Sweetheart, you are getting to that age where it’s really important to learn how to take care of yourself. This book covers most, if not all that you need to know to make sure you are fresh and clean when you leave the house.” You can offer a gift that contains a hygiene kit with a toothbrush, toothpaste, natural salts deodorant, a fragrant body wash and matching body spray (I.e. Bath & Body Works Warm Vanila Sugar). You can normalize it for her and say, “More people than you might think, face hygiene challenges at some time in their life.” I actually had an 8 year old with whom I had a similar conversation. Her teeth were thick with plaque and red from candy in the mornings. I asked her if she brushed her teeth in the morning. Her family was poor and she told me that her brother would take her toothbrush to use it. I put together a hygiene kit for her and told her to hide it in the house where her brother wouldn’t find it. It might be a good idea to inform your Principal about your plan, if you choose to go this route, in case you or your principal gets approached by an angry parent who objects to your gifts. If that should happen, I’d just apologize & say ‘we wanted to help without causing your daughter undue embarrassment’.

I would say you don’t, not if all you have about it is what’s in your question. Especially if the kid is young, like too young to have reliable autonomy regarding hygiene. As is, there are too many variables that are beyond your knowledge or comprehension. Besides, poor hygiene in itself isn’t particularly interfering with education and learning abilities, so in my view this would be an inconvenience at most. I don’t mean that you should just shrug it off and turn a blind eye, especially if you suspect some form of neglect, voluntary or not. I had a kindergarten student that smelled of urine. His clothes smelled even though he would not soil himself during school time. So I talked to his parent, privately and without the kid. I tried to keep it professional, straightforward and non judgmental : “I’ve noticed that X’s clothes regularly smell of urine. There have been no “accidents” at school, he is able to use the toilet all by himself. But accidents can still happen at home and he might be too shy to tell right away, thank you for being vigilant and making sure to dress him in a clean outfit in the morning.” The same mindful yet direct communication with the legal guardian can be applied to your situation. Then if the problem persists or if other significant clues hinted toward a difficult situation at home, I would recommend the involvement of a social worker to assist the parents and accompany the family through that process, in concertation with the school administration. Once a support network is in place, leave it to the social workers and the family to sort out. Hygiene issues can stem from a variety of situations from parental difficulties to poor living conditions, unpaid utility bills, to abuse or neglect. We cannot presume without actual involvement in the family’s life and we cannot offer advice on problems we don’t know. Ultimately, once steps have been taken to ensure the that the family is receiving help and the child’s welfare is monitored appropriately, our responsibility is to provide them an education in the same conditions as all other students.

You didn’t mention the age range of the child. That’s quite an important factor. At a certain age, as a teacher, I think it would be possible to lightly handle this successfully. You need to do it in a way that prevents the child from feeling singled out and/or humiliated. Please remember, though, that what smells ‘appropriate’ is entirely subjective. You may have an issue where it isn’t an issue for other people. As a general rule of thumb, though, it’s no bad thing to engender an interest in personal grooming and hygiene with children. So… How to do it? I think you incorporate a short spate of lessons into the general or, even, science curriculum. Treat body odors as a science lesson. Talk about soaps and body washes and antiperspirants etc. in an environmental context. Try get hold of a load of free samples and offer them to the class for judgement. Talk about the ingredients. Talk about their rating for being ecologically friendly. Talk about ‘scent notes’. Talk about how the same scent can smell differently when it reacts with an individuals genetic makeup. Get the whole class fascinated in the science and evolution of human smells! When I was little - I used to love smelling things. I’d find people’s perfumes, lotions and after shaves and I’d open them up and smell them. Sometimes I’d mix things together, much to the chagrin of my family, to make new and improved smells. Curiously, however, I did go through a phase (when I hit puberty) of finding the new smell of my armpits really intriguing. I could have benefited, hugely, from an exhaustive lesson on why girls start to smell a bit funky at a certain age and why that level of advertising of the ripeness isn’t such a great idea in modern society (it can be very counterproductive). So - that’s how I would tackle the situation. You don’t really have a right to impose your ideas about grooming/hygiene on another individual - however unpleasant you might find theirs. You can, as a teacher, come at it from every direction. That’s kind of the role of a teacher :) . Get the whole class, including ‘the child’, interested in the whole topic.

I will tell you the same thing I told the teachers, friends, school counselors, Princials, family members etc. who told me our daughter stinks. PLEASE tell her your self. When we aquired our daughter at the age of 14 [foster care] she had terrible hygiene. She never brushed her teeth, wouldn’t put on deodarant, we had to force her to shower [through lack of privileges]. I started watching her her do the deodarant and teeth as often as I could, but wasn’t always possible. Then I kept getting calls and emails about the odor “please discuss hygiene with your daughter” “Please make sure your daughter is wearing clean clothes” they would list how to how have good hygiene, like they were talking to me , like I had no idea how what hygiene was and that I had no idea she stunk. I would be very frustrated and respond as such. I would tell them I am FULLY aware she stinks, I KNOW how to have good hygiene , do not lecture me ,you have no idea how hard we’ve tried. I told them I have talked to her repeatedly , this time I will not because you need do it. She needs more than just me telling her. Just her parents telling her wasn’t motivating enough. She needed a little humility to realize she needed to take steps to be cleaner. Finally after they started telling her themselves , as well as my friends [who are like aunties] and her friends, she now really works on herself. We still struggle with regular teeth brushing, but it’s now at least once a day, daily showers , deodarant 2x a day, doesn’t rewear her clothes. I hate to say, but a little embarrassment goes a long way. As a school bus driver I find this works in general, slightly embarass a kid that won’t stop being terrible on the bus and he tends to stop. Some might think it’s heartless or cruel, I see it more as tough love. It would have been a worse situation to just keep on letting her stink.

What we have had to do at School is this: we have clean clothes ready for the child and then one of us “accidentally” spills something on this child. We then take the Child and have him/ her change and “ clean ” them up throughly. We put their clothes in the washer & dryer and send them home in their clean clothes. This usually has to happen 4–5 times and then the majority of parents send their child to School having bathed and with clean clothes. To talk to a child I have done the following: I sit the child down and plainly say, “ I need to talk to you about hygiene. If they are old enough to know what that means, good, if not, then you explain in simple terms, its washing each day , why, etc. You then have to ask the hard question: “ can you shower at-home,?” You will get all kinds of answers. Keep your voice and body language as neutral as possible. If the child cannot shower at home then you let them know you have some items if they need them. Be prepared with items, wash cloths, soap, whatever they need. Offer to be there early so they can clean up before school, offer to wash their clothes if its needed. Do your best to provide whatever they need. It such a hard conversation to have but most children have more self awareness then what we give them credit for. And chances are if you have noticed, so have others including other kids. I have also talked to Parents about their Child's hygiene It was a hard conversation because some parents became ( understandably so) extremely defensive. I reassure them that some children don't like to bathe, some have just picked bathtime as their favorite battleground and on rare occasions it was because the family was in shelters or homeless. I wish you the best of luck and I thank you for looking out for you Students.

Number 1# You Don't As human beings we are ridiculously uncomfortable with our biological responses to odor often eliciting inappropriate responses. If someone has an odor that offends us, it is not their responsibility to us to smell the way we want them too.. If we are offended by an odor it is not our right to “correct” the person of someone else. That being said, if a child has an odor and it is effecting personal interactions in class, 2 things: Is the odor because of a lack of knowledge with personal hygiene. If so, without singling out individuals, you can do a class module on hygiene. Make it fun top it off with gift bags of age appropriate pampering hygienic bliss. You can do this for very little by visiting a dollar store and creating scent filled sample size wonder. For teenagers or older kids add a couple of lottery baskets “Bigger Better Bling". If you discuss this plan ahead of time with your school counselor and principal there should be no problem with approval on how to tactfully Help your entire class rather than single out one individual. Secondly, If there is a health concern?? For instance Diabetes-can smell sickly sweet Anemia and mineral deficiencies-smell like Cat Pee. …Thats right the tell tell cat pee smell that many children get teased or blamed for poor hygiene is actually Ammonia byproduct from protein and mineral deficiency common to busy working households living on quick fry high calorie low nutrient food. Without access to fresh foods this is common and oddly overlooked. So if its Ammonia understand people don't always have the resources they need to be healthy, How can you help? If the health concern is more serious, like possible diabetes, notify the school nurse and discuss concerns with the parents. Hope this is helpful. Have an Adventure Making A Positive Difference In So Many Lives. Standing Ovation to the Teachers ! Thanks for All You Do.

I think this really depends on the age and maturity of the child. If the child is younger than 8 or so, I'd either mention it nicely to the parent if I have a good rapport with them, or I'd refer it to the nurse. They generally do wellness checks on the students, so that can easily be mentioned. If the child is upper elementary or middle school, I would work some personal hygiene lessons into class. I always called this “Adulting 101" with the older kids. I would focus a weekly “life hack" that ranged anywhere from personal hygiene to manners to managing money. It only took 5-15 minutes or so each week. There are always funny but informative videos you can find on sensitive topics. If that didn't work, I'd ask the child how things were going at home and proceed from there. Sometimes they will tell you the problem without you actually having to bring it up (parent working a lot, water got turned off, having to move between households, etc.). High schoolers are easier. If the kid is on a sports team, you could talk to the coach (without naming names) and ask them to remind the kids about hygiene. You can also just make a general PSA to remind everyone that soap, water, and deodorant are their friends and Axe isn't a substitute. Humor is helpful.

At my school, we are lucky enough to have a full-time nurse. She has made it her mission to deal with this issue which is very common among growing children, and like others below, does not necessarily stem from neglect on the part of the parent. Every year at the beginning of the school year, we have an assembly for the freshmen class and every child gets a bag with the basics: deoderant, toothbrush, toothpaste, a package of disposable razors, and a pack of moist towelletes. The nurse shows them what everything is for and the bag goes to their locker. They can refill it themselves or they can come in and ask for more. If I have this particular concern, I send the nurse an email, and then she finds the kid. If you’re not lucky enough to have this level of resources, then I would work with your colleagues to designate someone who is comfortable having those conversations and either do it assembly style the way we do, or be discrete and have one-on-one sessions. An answerer below said she worries it can be a very hard blow for a kid to hear this. I think that’s why the right messenger matters. I’m really great at communicating with kids, but not about stuff like this. When I worked at a school that didn’t have a nurse, I had one female colleague and one male colleague. He or she would take the student to their classroom and fold the odor issue into a host of hygiene issues that everyone worries about. This approach softened the blow.

Find a private time and place, and offer a solution…..have clean clothing and a shower available RIGHT THEN. Don’t put the child in the position of knowing they smell bad and having to continue sitting there with other children. Just plan ahead, get the shower and clothing, and decide how to succinctly and kindly say it, then do it. Let the child know you’ll begin washing and drying their clothing while they shower, and the following day they can shower again and have their original clean clothing to put back on. It works beautifully. I’ve helped children with this once using a nursing room shower, and another time, the gym shower. The children LOVED showering! We provided nice soap, a scrubber, shampoo and rinse, deodorant, comb and brush, tooth brush and tooth paste. They never resisted being able to clean up, instead, they often took a full period cleaning and grooming themselves. It was such a gift to everyone. Make sure you call parents and let them know what you’re doing and that someone is protecting the child when they’re vulnerable showering and grooming…..guarding the door. Make sure it doesn’t ever backfire. Have fun! It’s a great gift, always appreciated.

Are you smelling this odour every single day or has it only happened occasionally? If it is just once in a while, you should let it go as it can happen to anybody. Is this odour from what the child is eating or is it from a lack of cleanliness or proper hygiene? The age of the child makes a big difference. If it is a small child and you think that it is a problem, you could very gently speak to the parent privately so that they can try to rectify the situation. You have to be careful not to embarrass them. Let them know that this kind of thing happens so that they don’t feel like they are the only one who has been told this. If we are talking about an older child or a preteen, children this age don’t always realize when they are giving off an odour. It could be that they now need deodorant which they had never used before. It is possible that they are not showering enough or brushing their teeth regularly. Ideally, this child will probably take hearing this better from a teacher who is the same sex as them or from a teacher that they have a close relationship with. It should not be made to sound like it is an extremely big deal as this could cause further embarrassment. Just let them know that this is not uncommon as children are getting older and their bodies are changing. A caring teacher will be much kinder than a bully who makes fun of them for it if the issue is not addressed.

I can’t believe the below answer from a MALE councellor who suggests talking to the kid,, and blaming someone else for telling at the same time. Are you sure councelling is what you are supposed to be doing.?? I don’t think there could be anything worse for a young girl, than to be embarrassed by an older man, telling her she stinks. Why not also tell her you think she’s stupid and won’t amount to anything in life. That’s another thing teachers and school councellors are pretty good at - and usually wrong. The answer is obvious. The FEMALE teacher should call the girl’s mother and have a chat. Yes,, a CHAT. You don’t call the mother and TELL HER what’s wrong with her child. If fact you don’t call the mother and TELL her anything. For some reason, teachers always think they are right, and can’t fail.. Well, I can tell you absolute certainty teachers are wrong - A LOT. Have a friendly chat with the mother, and bring up the problem - in a nice way. You have no idea if this is a medical problem, a hygiene problem, or a household problem. You obviously don’t know. And don’t judge and DON’T go the teacher’s lounged later and gossip about the kid - like teachers do. Maybe the mother will understand and correct the problem by speaking to her child. If you MUST talk to the kid, be understanding and bring it up in compassionate way. I know teachers love humiliating kids, but seriously, don’t. Be nice to a young girl with a problem. That is all.

That’s a tough position to be in. When I was a young teen I had horrible BO and there were plenty of well meaning adults who tried to let me know. I’d recommend taking some additional detail about the situation . Are they about the age where they have hit puberty? Is the BO after recess/PE? Are they coming to school with BO and unwashed clothes? These details could provide more info on if this is a normal puberty issue, a hygiene issue, or a resource access issue. From there, just try to do it where the student’s peers will not hear or see and try to bring it up as “I noticed this and this is not a negative thing about you, but it can you and others. If so, have you tried xyz?” Just be prepared that the kid will still be embarrassed and may not react favorably. Chances are, if you’ve noticed, so have they. My final piece of advice is if your relationship with the kid is distant or not positive, you are not the person to tell them. Maybe they have a better relationship with another teacher you can talk to. I found that the teachers I liked least were more likely to mention my body oder and it was never well received. When a teacher I was close to finally mentioned it, I’d heard at least a dozen times before that.

I’m answering as a male middle school counselor who has delivered this message to many a child. Deliver it straight and don’t make a big deal of it. Don’t wait for the student to come to you, they almost certainly won’t and they need an adult to collaborate with so they can fix the situation. If they get upset when you talk to them, act surprised and say “this is pretty normal for your age, it’s really no big deal, but we do want to fix it if we can.” Most students take this information much better than you might think. Then comes the big three questions: Are you showering everyday?Do you wear deodorant everyday?Are you wearing fresh clothes everyday (including hoodies)?There might be an issue of poverty, such as an inability to do these three things or something like cat pee or cigarettes in the house. If that’s the case, talk to the school counselor or social worker and see what options you have. If it’s one of the three big things, stress you them that these three things have to happen everyday with no exceptions or they will definitely smell, and this is just part of growing up. Good luck!

It depends on the age of the child. Middle school for example you have the class puberty talk and let everyone know that they all should start wearing deodorant. Elementary school you ask the child about their hygiene practices and supplies. Based on their responses you either teach self care lessons on hygiene or reach out to the family with community resources saying something along the lines of, I was talking to your child today and they mentioned that you could benefit from some of these resources. If the child responds that they do not have access to hygiene equipment it may also be worth looking into a cps report to make sure the child is not being neglected. If you have had a conversation with the child and they have access and are regularly washing it may be a dietary or cultural thing that you are not used to. (Such as eating lots of curry or using oils for skin and hair maintenance.) in these instances you should not try to change these behaviors because of the smell, but instead take it as a learning opportunity.

I would think you don't. Perhaps set aside some time to teach the class about hygiene and laundry and housekeeping and hope it enlightens he who needs it and helps them all. I understand you have so much to do as is and we as parents should do our part but in this case flexibility and perspective is key. You are a teacher to enlighten and help a childs evolution and this is what one of your children need and from my perspective on society all could benefit from. Maybe ten minutes at the end of each day of a self- care month and go over handwashing, teeth brushing, laundry, hair washing, showers, dishes ie how often and how then discuss the why. Clean self and surroundings and let them teach you the benefits. It may not be what you expected but there is a lovely video Im sure you can find of a teacher who lined chairs in rows and taped two balloons together to the backs then demonstrated proper wiping techniques using the balloons in place of the bottom and realize your not alone. A brilliant teacher teaches what her students need to learn not just what they are told to teach. I also read of a teacher who had a box and she had her children drop notes in the box and she learned the most amazing things wo shaming anyone like who needed a hug, who was lonely at lunch etc. This may help you learn this child knows they smell but simply needs soap in their home. Best wishes, I applaud your caring heart.

Sometimes it’s the home environment. A nice way to do this is to get them a little gift of body wash. Then when they come & still smell bad, you ask, did you not like my gift? You may find out that the family does not have running water or other issues. But that is the way I would approach it. If you try to do it in a nice way first. Then if you have found that they have running water & still doesn’t change their hygiene, then say it to them. Tell them that you are concerned that other kids may pick on them because they have body odor. I have a 14 year old grandson that smells like a man who worked out side all day. We have given him body wash & deodorant but I think it’s the age where he just doesn’t care. We tell him he stinks, he will shower but it’s just not on the top of his list of priorities! So I wish you luck!

You could start by understanding body chemistry - because the child smells to YOU doesn’t mean they do to others. Ask other teachers to take a subtle sniff. If they smell the same thing, have a private chat with the child about basic hygiene (awkward, but ask the nurse for tips). Then suggest they ask their parents for deodorant, because all the other kids are using it as well (that’s tricky, as parents can be stupid about implied criticism and where they find it). They could be rough-and-tumble kids who sweat more than normal - which is rough for everybody, but nothing that can be controlled. If you’re the only one who detects an odor, then human reproduction is telling you that person isn’t genetically compatible. It’s complex and kind of fascinating. On an informal study, we had two male lifeguards working at my facility. One kid was simply rank to me, even after his shower, while another boy had little “aroma”. For another guard, it was just the opposite. The guard I couldn’t smell would remind her of rotten onions, while the boy I was off-put by didn’t smell to her. Women Can Smell Genetic Differences for more information, as well as here: Scents and Sensibility

I would pull them aside away from other students and let them know they may not notice it because they are used to it, if it's a body odor that can be fixed with deodorant I would also give them one of those trial size deodorants because you don't really know what is going on at home that the family would ignore it. If it's another type of odor saying something could embarrass them. A couple of years ago I lived with my boyfriend and his family, his mother had 8 or 9 dogs large dogs in the house as well as a few cars causing the house to smell horrible any fabrics in the house picked up the smell as well. I never really went out but I felt embarrassed for his high school aged son and his mother who had no idea how bad the smell was.

This is a regular issue for us middle school teachers. Here’s how we deal with it. Get sample sizes of deodorant, soap, shampoo, etc… for all of the students. Give them to all of the students as a little gift bag, along with a quick lecture about taking care of your body. That is, don’t make it personal to that one student, but make it a class-wide lesson.If that doesn’t work, have a teacher of the same gender speak to that particular student personally.If that doesn’t work, get the parents involved.

Don’t. Don’t you dare. Unless this Odor is of some medical condition like yeast infection or wound infection mind your damn business. Your business is to teach and educate. If the child appears neglected, unwashed and clothes unlaundered and or potentially underfed that would be different. That would be guidance, assistant principal have a pow wow and figure out a course of action. Under no circumstances are you to play a role in this child feeling shame. Teaching Stories: I had an entire class that smelled like body odor, thought I was slick and offered 5 points on the next test to everyone who brought deodorant to class. They all seemed to bring a deodorant and they all continued to have the same odor hahahaaha. That was a great failure I will never forget.

You have to tell them because it’s bad for them and it’s bad for everyone else. As a teacher I’m sure you know how to talk to kids, you could say like “sweetie you’re growing up so you’re going to have to start using deodorant like adults do”. If you teach small kids it’s impossible not to have to act like a parent sometime. Adults have to take responsibility for these things if their parents are unaware or negligent, because otherwise you’re subjecting the kid to being looked down on, or even abused for it. It could damage their social life, etc. if they don’t have proper hygiene. It’s your job to look after the welfare of the kid to a reasonable extent. That’s what a teacher is. If you’re a male teacher though and the kid is a girl, probably best to get a female colleague to talk to her.

Do not shame the child! It may not be their fault, or there may not be anything they’re able to do about it. Speak with a parent discreetly and with nonjudgmental tone. They may be on medication that makes them smell bad, it could be from specific foods, spices or herbs the family uses. It could be from coated tongue from constipation or a nutritional deficiency. It could be from not having access to bathroom, hot running water, or sharing bathroom with many others, not having soap, deodorant, hair products, or having a hormone imbalance or disease of some type. Maybe the parent just has to make sure they wash their armpits often and get a mild natural unscented deodorant. Some polyester, acrylic, and other synthetic manmade fibers or materials in clothes, underwear, and shoes, don’t “breathe” and cause excessive perspiration and or an odor from the chemicals used in manufacturing or stain repellant, waterproof or fireproof coatings.

You could try talking directly to the parents about it. There's always the possibility that the kid has a health issue. Many suggested speaking to the child directly, but since you're asking this question here, I'm sure you've thought about it and seem to be looking for other responses as well as wanting to know how to even bring it up to the kid per se. Doing a class presentation could make that child the target of mockery since many would guess who it is directed at (if you can smell the kid, so can the other children). I don't recommend it. Have you tried asking other teachers what they would do in your place? Can you ask a social worker or maybe even the school principal? As one person said in her response, the child could be hurt. I, personally, would've been embarrassed. This is probably why you want advice, so I suggest asking around at work for thoughts on how to proceed.

A teacher on here had the best answer. She gave the child a “Prize” in private after class one day a gift 🎁 bag or box (she had 2 and gave them both prizes.) You can get nice things at the dollartree ( unless you can get free donations from a shelter etc) a bright bag full of items needed ; a colorful toothpaste and brush, deodorant , shampoo and fancy soap , gum and a small trinket examples a nice candle etc all for under 10 dollars . Maybe tie a balloon on the bag then you can Kindly and discreetly address the issue and make the child happy thinking they won a prize🙂 Tell the child they gave the best answer in class to question x that day. Showed kindness to classmate x, had the most interesting story, was the most quiet today with “Your migraine” best drawing , funniest answers ….you get the Idea 💡

I was this kid. I the teacher took me out of class and took me down to the counselor's office, and said. “she has an odor and i will not tolerate it in my classroom.” and he left.. really old guy. this was 2008, i was in 7th grade. the counselor and assistant principle smelled me.. and took me to my parents house.. needless to say, my mother wasn’t happy. I have a condition that causes me to perspire more than normal. still to this day my parents were trying everything they could to suppress it. While, it could be just part of the child’s culture because there are different groups of people who practice different cleansing methods, I would suggest talking to the parents about it but in a not so abrasive manner.

As a teacher, I would leave this conversation to the school nurse. Speak to the nurse in advance so they can have some supplies ready in the clinic. This way the conversation can be completely private and the nurse can determine what’s causing the problem. This will keep the student from feeling awkward in class with you. When the hormones hit people stink. This happens in a wide range of ages and sometimes young people have to try different deodorants to find one that works for them. The student could have a medical problem, be homeless, or simply not bathe. We had to put up with a 10 year old whose underarms smelled like rotten onions. He felt like we were punishing him by marching him right back into the shower and demanding that he use soap. He was the one punishing us with his pre-pubescent odor!

What is the age group of your students? If they’re middle school and up, pull the student aside privately to discuss hygiene concerns. You can start out by asking if everything is fine at home, ask if maybe they aren’t able to get some necessities. It’s entirely likely the family doesn’t have enough money to bathe every day or for toiletries. If it’s elementary school students, you can do something similar to what my daughter’s teacher did if you can get some funding. She bought a little bag of toiletries for all her students, with a travel size toothbrush, toothpaste, comb, bar of soap, and shampoo. She also did a small lesson on personal hygiene with the whole class. I know that might be a bit hard to do because it can cost a lot of money, but if you can get donations, you might be able to do it, and it could help the whole class in many ways.

Probably not directly. It can happen that the other children notice the problem and tell a child, which can be as effective as anything you can do. If the child is a teenager, it might be an idea for the whole class to have one or two sessions on personal hygiene. Something similar might be carried with a class of younger children, pitched at the right level for the age group. However, before taking any action I would mention the problem to your head teacher and ask for some advice. If the problem persists, and you happen to meet the child’s parents, probably at a parents’ evening, you might find an opportunity to gently enquire as to how often the child takes a shower or a bath—but tread carefully!

I remember my class teacher in Year 5 (age about 10) bringing this up and she did it well. I imagine there were a couple of kids in the class who had this problem and the teacher didn’t want to single them out or embarrass them, so she spoke to the whole class about it together. I think it might have been part of a PSHE lesson. The gist was, you’re starting to get into puberty and so are going to need to take personal hygiene more seriously and maybe wear some deodorant. I like that approach because body odour is something that everyone is going to have to deal with at some point in their lives, and 10 year olds don’t really see it as an issue or something they need to control. Her using it as a teaching moment didn’t shame anyone or turn it into a personal affront; it was presented as something that everyone should start thinking about doing.

I am an elementary school teacher, and I don’t. If a child has a concerning body odor, clothing that is dirty or doesn’t fit, I contact the school counselor and/or the social worker and nurse. I work in a poor school district so we have several support staff to help the kids with food, clothing and medical care. Usually the nurse can wash their clothes or give them a bath, and the social worker contacts the family or does a home visit to see if they are in need of anything. I love my students and care about them, but taking those matters into my own hands isn’t my job especially when we have staff that provide help. Reach out to your school’s counselor or nurse if you have one first and see what they suggest before talking to the student.

Please don’t. You can approach it sensitively with the child’s parents/carers, in a non judgemental way, not in earshot of the child. Don’t assume the parents/carers don’t already know of it. Don’t assume they do or do not have resources to wash. Please keep an open mind and be respectful of their circumstances. You can teach the whole class a lesson on personal hygiene and different ways all people may undertake this. Some children do not have resources to wash. Some have sensory/neurological issues preventing them from washing as others would. Eg. Some autistic people use baby wipes as they can’t stand water on their skin.

Thank you for your request that I share my opinion on this topic. I will share with you from my personal experiences. (it’s long, as usual) At one time I was an interpreter for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, and also an Instructional Assistant for these same children, k-12 -depending on the needs of year. I spent the majority of my years in one elementary school class enrolled with 12–14 children k-6 students. We had a very small, almost skeletal boy, who I will name Carl. Carl was born with severe deafness. Perhaps their frustration or being too young or for whatever reason, his parents abandoned/safe surrendered him as a weeks old infant. From the time he was born until the age of 7.5 years he went from foster home to foster home several times per year. He came to our classroom only knowing “command” signs: ‘toilet’, ‘eat’, ‘drink’, bed’, ‘sit’ etc., a total of about 30 words. He never received hearing aides. He had never attended school for more than 2–3 weeks per year since kindergarten. He was considered “wild”; one remark in his file said he was a child of “low intelligence with a feral upbringing”. He was the poster boy for being a “born loser’ because no one in his 7.5 years had ever loved him or bothered to learn how to communicate with him. He came to us with scars all over his body from abuses he had suffered at the hands of “care givers”. So yes, when he was dropped off into our class, he had no idea who we were or why he was suddenly in a room full of strangers, adults and children, and he reacted as any frightened child would. We were fortunate that we were able to reach him, help him feel safe, and we increased his vocabulary by almost 80–100 words per day until he caught up to his age level. He was BRILLIANT! As in most classrooms we had “group” learning depending on the level and understanding the children were put into the group that could best help them progress to the next level. We had one Deaf Educator, and two Instructional Aides. → Carl and I were the first to make a trusted connection, so most of the groups he was assigned to were mine. When Carl came to my first group of the day, you could literally smell him before he got to the table, a combination or cigarette smoke, alcohol, urine, filthy clothes, and ‘sour’. His skin was dry and he would try to lick himself to relieve the itch and sometimes pain. He wasn’t nurtured in his new home and rarely had clean clothes, and his hygiene was also absent. → NONE of the situations that Carl had to endure were his fault or responsibility. The care he had received his entire life was that of an unwanted dog. To speak to the “care givers” about any subject Carl was involved in was like trying to converse with a log. They were there to “put a roof over his head and keep him alive, after that [their] responsibility ended.” I was known in our classroom as the ‘organizer’, the ‘clean freak’, and everyone knew I brushed and flossed my teeth, and washed my hands often enough that my first year in that classroom all the kids got together and bought me a new toothbrush, floss, and a small bottle of Purell for Christmas! In order to allow Carl to feel safe, and for the other children to not make fun of him, I made it a habit that when everyone came to my group throughout the day, I would hand out baby wipes and have all of us, myself included, wash our face, hands, and put healing lotion on our hands and arms. It took less than 3 minutes, and after the first week they didn’t even wait for instructions, they just began the routine. This seemed to help his situation without causing him to feel embarrassed over things he had never learned how to do on his own and no one had done for him in the past. No one questioned it because it seemed like something I would do because of my personality. The entire class was also given a small 10 minute ‘hygiene minute’ every day for about a month; teaching us all the importance of basic hygiene, brushing teeth, taking a shower, how to wash hands often and well, how to use the toilet properly, when and how to ask parents for deodorant or new socks, -we’re talking B A S I C things that needed to be taught. The other children had no clue this was directed primarily to Carl because we taught it to everyone like we did other total class subjects. “Matthew, have you ever forgotten to take a shower? How did you feel once you remembered? “Lisa, do you brush your teeth as many times as Ms. Brown? (everyone laughed at that one and she said “NO ONE brushes their teeth as much as Ms. Brown!”) “Just mercy! I got home last night and I had stinky feet! (more laughter) Carl, how do you get rid of stinky feet?” …and so on. After a while he caught on and began washing and trying to come in clean clothes, although he certainly did not get help from home. He even approached us from time to time when he spilled during lunch, “How do I get this out of my shirt before I go back to class?” → All of this to say if you have a child with poor hygiene chances are it is not his or her fault in any way, and kindness and compassion is the only way to resolve the issue. If you can find a way to include everyone in on the lesson it will cause less embarrassment for the single child. If you cannot, add this to the list of ‘extra’ things you will now get to do. This child is being neglected and if you notice, you can do something that can change their life for the better. I am happy to report that while Carl was with us those couple of years he grew tremendously in mind and spirit, had friends, trusted a few more adults, and his behaviours settled in to average for his age within a month or so. When he left us he cried because he had felt love and compassion. He had become so much more of his true self. All he needed was someone to patiently teach him. Be kind and compassionate.

I would speak with the parents first-if it’s a young child. The child may have an ear or throat infection, or the child could be incontinent. A small child might not know how to clean himself after defecation. There are many health reasons to be ruled out. Don’t assume the child is dirty. Some. children entering puberty begin to have an odor and need deodorant and instructions on bathing. A very young girl may have started menstruating an not been taught how to manage it. Some schools have a stash of supplies including deodorant and A teacher can talk to older children about their body changes In a science class as a group without embarrassing the child. Coaches can talk to kids one on one.

Very very very….carefully, if at all. The child probably already is aware that something is “off”— as no doubt, peers probably have already made comment or actions about it. My suggestion would be to refer this to your school nurse or public health partner for your school district, to approach the child. You don’t give an age—if it is a young child, the situation is really challenging as it is the parents’ responsibility to ensure cleanliness and sometimes parents are extremely reactive as they perceive this as a personal issue and become very upset. It could be a health issue or lack of awareness on the home front. Again, refer and in the meantime, accept the child with grace.

Find out about a child’s homelife, he/she may live in an environment that cleanliness is not possible. Believe it or not, some families don’t have access to clean water, facilities, or money for laundry. If this is not the problem, ask the parents if their is something physically/medically wrong. Buy a bar of sweet smelling soap and have the child come into class a few minutes early to wash his hands and face. Notice that none of these “telling” the child that he smells bad. Don’t do that to the child. Work with the adults to get things back on track, but don’t lay it on the kiddo himself.

I wouldn’t tell the child at all. That would hurt their feelings and embarrass them. Instead, I’d reach out to the parent and gently bring it up with them. Be direct, “I don’t know if you’re aware of this problem but ‘Tommy’ has an odor about him. I can’t tell if it’s his clothing or personal hygiene, but I need to make you aware of it. I haven’t said a word to ‘Tommy’. We need to be delicate.” And you really do. Especially if he’s perspiring, nervous about school, and parents haven’t yet introduced him to deodorant. Or if he’s going through puberty and parents haven’t noticed. Good luck!

I would wrinkle my nose and ask them why they smell like a sweaty puppy-dog? Just very matter of fact, but like a nosy aunt. Not hurtful, and not even very interested. Just incidental. The thing is, it would make it into a “not a big deal” situation, where having a serious talk might be hurtful. I had a pt who was very smelly, of course, it was deep summer and he had quite a walk getting to me, but I basically said, “You need to wash your shirt and get the strong man deodorant for the big and strapping young lad you are.” Of course, I am very motherly, so my nagging is basically assumed to be caring rather than hurtful. He washed his laundry and got deodorant. Boys frequently just don’t know. I think people have varying degrees of sense of smell. Like the people who cannot cook, for example. I am convinced that the smell just does not entice some people. There is a guy who works with my partner, and he is referred to as “stinky-his name.” By piping up now when this child is at a formative age, you save him this humiliation later in life. If it is a she, and it is unkempt period hygiene, even more important. Don’t feel bad. You are a teacher and your oath is to help these little individuals thrive in life. This is a difficult but important lesson.

Contact the School Nurse (School Phone or Cell Phone) Tell the School Nurse about the student. Usually the School Nurse will ask you to send the student with a pass to see the Nurse. Write the pass. Ask the student to meet you outside the door of the room and give the student the pass to see the Nurse. Tell the student that the School Nurse wants to see him or her. Don’t give the student too many details. Just send the student with a pass to the School Nurse. If the student returns to class on the same day, talk to them privately outside the classroom door before they enter the class. Usually this is rare as the School Nurse is likely to talk and counsel the student and have the student return to class after conferring with parent. If the student asks why you sent them to see the School Nurse, you say it’s about you respecting his or her privacy. Good idea to confer with the School Nurse as soon as possible.

Please, tell the parent. The child may live in an abusive home or be from a very poor family. There are many normal looking in children just barely surviving quite horrid circumstances. This child may know they smell but have to live in extreme denial to survive many hidden home issues. Tell the parent. Make sure this child is getting proper care. Perhaps child is depressed. Ie: Only 1 parent at home No one to help them. Could be very lost. Or the child may have a health issue ( body chemistry). Could be so many things. Please, talk with the parent from a view of how can the school co identically help. Dont blame parent just look to ‘help' If child is abused at home, please report it

It's better for them coming from a teacher than from a peer. If you are a teacher you know school age children are not the kindest beings. Be open about it. Talk about hygiene in class in general etc,. How body odour can happen to anyone, it's not a problem. Show videos even. Give it a week before pointing out to that student. Give it straight in a neutral tone. If they seem embarrassed tell them in this job you have said the same thing to hundreds of kids. it's nothing. Also please take note of how culturally appropriate where you live. In some countries it could be an absolute no no to talk about.

I’m sorry I don’t understand the question are you trying to explain pheromones to a child or are they just stinky and you want that problem to be addressed? I would say don’t take it up with the child take it up with the parents. it might hinder on a self-esteem for the child and it wouldn’t be right. As a teacher you can teach the kids all together as a classroom so the child is not singled out about handwashing and Good hygiene though. Using soap washing stinky areas such as under the arms feet behind ears etc. I also think you might want to check with the principal to know what is acceptable in the school district because everyone is so affected by everything nowadays it’s hard to know what is OK or deemed appropriate for you to teach and what is not.

I think you have to be really careful because this child probably has a terrible home situation. if it’s their clothing- they seem to be wearing the same thing over and over again- perhaps They don’t have clothes. I think it be wonderful to buy clothing, wash it at home so it doesn’t look like it’s brand new with tags put it in a paper bag and after class when absolutely no one is there give it to the child and say these look like they’re probably your size - you can have them. Don’t give a reason why. Be sure the style and everything will look nice to the child not nice to you and how you would want them to dress. Pay special attention to what they’re into and what they’re interested in as far as characters or any motifs that may be on the clothing. As a good teacher who cares pay special attention to whether or not this child is being bullied or teased. If they need washing or deodorant speak to them very privately and very gently in a way that doesn’t embarrass them and perhaps even say, when I was your age I had exactly the same thing. Normalize it - tell them that they’re one of your favorite students and you only want to help them. And that you’ll do everything you can.

Tell them privately that as children grow up they tend to have a stronger odor and need to shower more often as they mature, just ask them if they skipped their daily shower today or were they doing something to make them sweat because you call smell the funk. As a restaurant manage I had to have this conversation quite a few times, the best way is straight forward with no judgement in your tone. Number 1 rule to follow was praise in public, reprimand in private. So go with did you skip your daily shower today, it gives them a out about stinking all the time without too much embarrassment.

Since this is outside of the scope of teaching, and falls under parenting, you should have a private conversation with the parent about it, and offer any solid documented advice from authorities such as “the health department recommends…” so they don’t blame you. If the parents resist or seem abusive, call CPS and let them deal with it. If they are receptive, keep reading! Their kid may simply rinse off rather than soaping up the critical areas, or may have inherently stinky feet or other issues. Explain to the parents that at times the odor can be severe, and can not only become a distraction for other kids, but a concern for bullying. Suggest they talk to their kid about the proper way to shower, and why (how fast odor causing bacteria replicate, how to get rid of the bacteria). If these options don’t work, try a bubble bath with deodorant liquid bath soap. Sitting and soaking in a bubble bath for 20 minutes will help. Ask them to provide the proper tools, such as deodorant bar soap in a bath net, deodorant liquid bath soap and a washcloth, deodorant, sweat block cream for feet, a change of socks mid-day, etc. The odor issue may not go away 100%, but it should improve.

If there is a consistent odor and it is impacting the child’s learning and social experiences or those of others I would want to do something - for the child’s sake. But how you do that will depend on the age of the child. If they are young, they have no control over what may be causing the odor. I caring conversation with a parent that includes a description of the odor and concern about their learning/social experiences, along with an understanding of difficult situations and offer to help find resources that might help. It’s a tough thing - but done in a caring manner can often help to find a solution and build a positive, rather than a defensive relationship. If the student is older and has control over how they smell, have that same caring conversation with them.

This came up once when I taught at Murry Bergtraum HS in Manhattan. A girl had body odor and I noticed this, as well as students. I discussed this with other teachers and we decided that I should inform the girl's phys ed teacher, and I did. I found it that the teacher encouraged her to use deodorant, and she did. More often I dealt with some students who had bad breath due to certain spicy foods, wearing braces, etc. A more potent and pungent body odor problem I dealt with was at Abraham Lincoln HS, with a few girls who wore ethnic clothing. Some of these kids had only a few changes of outfits and kids would complain about their body odor. I felt badly but once again I approached the phys ed teacher.

I taught middle school for 13 years and this came up. If you have a good relationship with a student, you can talk with the person individually. With middle school students, I would add that hormonal changes make for changes in body odor. I would also say that someone had the same conversation with me. Sometimes I would also call the parents. With some students, their body odor might be from lack of bathing facilities as they are homeless. In that case, I set it up that the student could take a shower at school before classes, preferably in the nurse’s office.

You don't. You're their teacher, not a nurse maid. Do they seem like they are not being taken care of at home? If they are, get the authorities involved. If not, there could be a number of reasons why the child has an odd odor, from diet to medications. Suck it up or change jobs.

When I was student teaching, we had a boy in the school who smelled really bad. I had to fight hard not to gag when helping him one on one with his math. He was also ostracized by his classmates because of his smell. We found out that the home he came from was not a clean home. There were lots of dogs that peed all over his clothes (both clean and dirty), and they often didn't have running water for bathing. I don't know all the details, but it sounded like a hoarding situation to me. We finally found a solution that worked for him/us. As soon as he got to school he would shower in the boy's locker room. While he was showering we would speed wash and dry his clothes in the home-ec room. He knew he smelled, but there wasn't much he could do about it at home. Everyone was happier when he was able to clean up at school.

It really just depends on how old the child is. I think if the kid is at least in 6th grade (middle school), I’m pretty sure they know or they don’t care. If they’re in elementary, I see no problem with just straight up telling them that they have a strong smell coming from them or their clothes. If it makes you feel better, you can lie or essentially make a euphemism, telling the kid that there’s a smell coming from their backpack, or a certain article of clothing.

Having been the child in this scenario I will tell you that however you do it the child will be devastated. I'd just come out and say it, in private of course. In my case the odor was caused because I had too much of the bacteria that naturally lives on our skin. For years I had to wash with the same soap that surgeons use to prep.for surgery. In my 20s things seemed to level out and I no longer have that problem.

I had 6th graders who all had odors. So we had discussion of what happens as they beginto grow. How they have hormones and their sweat glands go wild. That bacteria grows in dark damp areas like the underarms. We discussed the need for frequent showers or at least washing up. I taught in a rual area so not everyone paid attention. I got little dollar store deoderants. If they came in from recess smelling or just were smelling, usually in the afternoon, I’d hand them their deoderant. I don’t know the age or situation you refer to, but this might give someone some ideas.

My daughters teacher sent out a message to all the parents asking that we buy and teach our kids about deodorant and hygiene. I'm not sure if this is something they do regardless or if there is a specific child but this way it didn't embarrass any one child. If the issue continues I would definitely speak one on one with the child. Its better than other kids making fun of them. Unfortunately parents aren't always there to teach their children these basic life skills so you are really doing the child a favor

It depends on the age of the child. Some children are so neglected they do not have access to the luxury of hot water, soap and towels. And this might reflect the state of the residence they are living in. If its a young child its to surmise the parent and have a word with the parent. If its an older child, it does not change the initial worry that they might be living in dire circumstances. And older child you could have a word with to decide whether a social worker needs to be involved. Be sad if its all round neglect, child under weight, failing to thrive, not participating in school activities, a loner. Tired and wane looking, etc. The worry is the child having unwashed problems, might be indicative of much more serious problems. And its the child having to deal with it.

Pull them aside si you are out of earshot of anyone who might overhear and tell them tactfully. By school age most children are capable of having a mature conversation when the situation warrents it. If that fails or you are to scared to then send a letter home with them for their parents. If you go that route then you better make sure of the wording, because you will have some parents who will run right to the school board and file a complaint against you. As long as it is done the right way it will not matter if they do. Just do not give them any ammunition to goto the boards with.

I would tell the parent first. Some kids will change into a ‘favourite’ sweater or pair of jeans as soon as mom or dad goes out the door to work and they sometimes don’t realize how smelly it is. We had a grade 7 girl who stank of urine and who was ostracized by her classmates. They made it clear she stank so we didn’t need to point it out to her. With a female teacher present we spoke to the parent about possible health or psychological issues but the mother was in denial.

I would take them to a peaceful place at school and then sit down on the grass with them. They would ask you for the reason why you are alone in the place. I would ask them to lay down on the grass and smell it. After a few minutes I will ask them again what do you smell like the odor? When they found out they were the reason who had the smell of their body. They might feel embarrassed about it and I would tell them how to reduce the bad smells. That’s what I did when they had an odor.

I suggest that you just allow them to have an open discussion about body odor and good grooming. I believe all of them can comment on how they can make themselves well groomed. One technique is to ask them some advice about a student’s problem regarding his underarm odor and allow them to write their own ideas on the board. Then collate all of their best answers and let them react to any one of them .Just tell them to write a sentence reaction to it in a sheet of paper later on. A magazine article can also be used or a related story can do. Just tell them that there are no wrong answers and that all answers are welcome. I hope this can help.

One on one. Quietly and sincerely. Something like, “everybody has a natural scent. It gets stronger around your age. Sometimes it is a bacteria that gives off the odor. To help with our scent we put on deodorant. To help not feed bacteria, we need to be methodical. Washing regularly, changing clothes as it holds the bacteria and scent. It is our sweat that feeds the bacteria. So antiperspirant is used by many people. Women often use perfumes and men often use colognes. Many people are sensitive to scent. To be kind we try not to be offensive with our scent. Our own noses are amazing. We can blank out any smell very quickly. So we can't smell bad breath or body odor. I am happy to help and will let you know if you need more deodorant. You can help me too :) No reason to be embarrassed. Or awkward. I might even go so far as to give a lesson to the whole class. It is a topic often glossed over by parents and educators. Peace

As a child in puberty in middle school just remind the class “remember to put in deodorant for the sake of others” this really isn’t complicated you don’t need to play mind games or some shit hell if a teacher walked up to me and told me I stink I wouldn’t even mind because shit I geuss I do

I have had to do this many times and it never got easier. I taught 7th and 8th grades and this was an issue. I would pull the student aside when their friends wouldn’t notice. I would give them a quick talk, saying I noticed they are maturing and that body odor came with that. I also kept travel size deodorant for males females. I would give them one of those so they could use it that day. It always easily fixed the issue without embarrassing the student.

It depends on the age of the child I think, because you could find a little book about hygiene for the class and read it and do a little activity where you quiz them on it and then give the little incentive of a sucker and it might stick in their brains a little more so when that child goes home they go back a little more aware. Additionally, this is coming from a sorry person that experienced it where even after deodorant and being very aware of keeping their pits down, puberty was not very kind to me in the smell department in 4–5th grade.

Carefully. And have you identified the odor? Years ago two fellow, young students came to school smelling of what I now know was sex. Is it possible to find out what bathing arrangements there are at home? My mother only allowed weekly baths. If I had not washed the offending parts in a basin, it would have been ugly. Could you offer a towel and the use of school showers? Could you maybe introduce a class on hygiene? Touchy, huh?

How old is the child? If he is under 16 years of age I would address this issue with the child’s parents. Spare the child the embarrassment. The parents might be able to resolve this issue without drawing attention to it. Perhaps there is an issue with the child not having access to resources necessary to keep himself and his clothing clean. He will not want to pressure his parents with added concerns. The parents need to know. They may be able to ensure the child bathes more often, wears clean clothing, uses deodorant or perhaps seek medical advice if necessary. They might ask for help if they realize that their child cannot access necessary resources. This is the parents issue to address. As parents we are responsible to ensure our children are safe and healthy. Having a bad odour is neither safe or healthy. Address this issue with the child’s parents.

To address the situation, you will need to be discreet and kind first. Then directly address the odor problem, whether it be hair, breath, body or foot odor, urine/poop or dirty clothing. You might query that child whether their home situation is preventing good hygiene. This child may already know there’s a problem but not have the resources to take care of it themselves. You will likely have to involve parents or guardians as a next step. Having you address it now will help the child in the future.

You don’t!!! I would ask your counselor to speak with the child. If you don’t have a counselor, there must be a school nurse. Either one of them should handle this for you. If there isn’t a resource, as I suggested, I would ask the parent for a conservation with you. Have you ever watched on youtube the programs about hoarding? I saw one where the children of the home knew they smelled funny but they didn’t know what to do about it. Perhaps there is a reason for the odor that the child has no control over. There are agencies that deal with home health issues and I would guess this fits into that category.

I wouldn't suggest telling the child. That will only embarrass the kid. If you notice it, then others most likely have too and you don't want to add to that. I would first talk to the parents about it. Let them know the situation and how noticeable it is. If that doesn't work and you have to tell the child, do it in private. Make sure you have a guidance counselor or school psychologist with you.

You don't single them out. You teach the whole class about hygiene and the importance of wiping well, showering frequently, washing their hair, brushing their teeth etc… if that doesn't improve things then I suggest talking to the parents about it. If they're under 10 then definitely talk to the parents. Wiping can be a tough skill for kids to learn and they need help with hair washing and bathing private areas. Hopefully the parents will step up.

In the 1970s - 1980s I taught at a church-sponsored boarding high school in eastern Kentucky; we also had lots of day students from the community. There was no county water utility, so all of the ‘townies’ had a well with a pitcher pump, no pressurized hot water for a shower. Hazel Green Academy had a 200 foot well to very stinky, sulfurous water, but at least we had hot water in the boys’ and girls’ dorms and the classroom building. Truth be told, I can’t say the dorm students smelled any better than the townies, [or faculty, for that matter!!!] but there was one town girl brought to the attention of staff meeting that the coach was told to make her take a shower at school at least once a week after P.E., even though she was from a very fundamentalist family opposed to taking clothes off. I’m sure glad I taught social studies rather than gym!

I would check with administration first and get their advice. If you have a school nurse you could refer the child to them. If there are showers in the school you could get permission for the child to use those.If there is a low income situation at home your district may have a fund to assist with clean clothing. Nothing should be said to the child in the prewsence of other children. All conversations about this issue should be confidential and trteated with sensitivity. In direct talks with the child, one on one and alone, you could gently inquire as to bathing facilities at home. You could ask about a need for more clothes. The age of the child is also important. Ask around your district there will be resources one would hope. Good luck.

Very sensitively. I’m sure you've already taken them aside to find out about their circumstances at home. Do they have access to washing facilities? Is the problem due to ignorance? You didn't give the age of the student, so it's difficult to say more without additional information. Address the problem as you see fit only once you have full knowledge of their circumstances at home.

You don't tell the “child”. You tell the childs mother in private. If the child is a teen, then you have a word with him/her in private. Aswell as sending a letter to the parent. It can be sorted out if you go the right way about it. Just don't point the child out. That's not a nice thing to do. Good Luck. 😊

First, ask your Principal how they’d like you to handle it. If they leave it up to you, tell the parent, not the child. The parent may not be giving the child regular baths, so hopefully she’ll start bathing her child more often. Or, are the child’s clothes dirty when they come to school? The parent may not be washing their clothes often enough. If the problem persists, you may need the principal to talk to the parent.

At one school I taught in students made it very clear they did not want a boy in their class as he certainly had an door. Teachers did not need to tell him, so the question became “what do we do?” The sports teacher volunteered to talk to him and persuaded him to shower before school every morning at school. Deodorant was offered too. The student had problems at home and kids being kids, he was not popular at all at school. Difficult….

I would wait until the end of the day, and address the class about a few other issues, and my last issue would be ,” You guys are old enough to know better, and soon I’m gonna start handing out towels and sending people to the showers! I don’t want to smell anyone with too much perfume or cologne on, and I don’t want to keep smelling people that likes to shoot basketball before class or run to school period , because they need know how to use soap and water…. This way, I’m not being up front in their face, and I’m not singling out anyone, not to mention that a (Friend) close peer may say something to the student on the way home.

We had a similar issue when I was a student in the 8th Grade. One science lab, 15 minutes before the class was to end, our teacher asks all the girls to leave the class and go out. Then she proceeds to lay down the truth bomb at us. That the boys need to start using deodorant. As a student, it felt very respectable the way she managed the situation. We all knew who she was talking about but rather than targetting one specific student, she talked to the entire class regarding personal hygiene. In my opinion, it was a very graceful and effective way of getting the message accross.

Clue the nurse in ahead. Send them on an errand to the nurse. Let the nurse take care of it. That is what they do. They even have samples of deodorants, shampoos, and soaps, etc. they can send home. That way, you have not lost a relationship with the child that would embarrass them every day in your class.

My wood stove, my only heat, was vandalized and it made my whole house and everything in it smell like a fire. Of course the students said they smelled weed. My experience was that the best way to tell students embarrassing stuff was to ask them to a meeting, and to bring one of their trusted friends. Then record it, if things go south.

You don’t . Talk to the parents, discreetly. Don’t embarrass the child, please. Some cultures don’t see the need to ‘cover’ body odours. Gently explain that the child could be bullied or ostracised because of it. The solution maybe as easy as a $2 roll-on deodorant. .. but talk to the parents first.

Age matters. As an elementary teacher, I would gently mention it to the child's parent when it became obvious that the other kids were noticing. I wouldn't want to embarrass the student, and really it's the parents who should be on top of their kid's hygiene habits.

Hey! Thank you for requesting my answer to this question. Would be happy to answer! This answer depends on their age. If they are young like toddler or 7–8 then maybe make it a game.
