A deodorant game with the class?? Sounds weird but an idea. Maybe the first child to quickly spray there Body and put on roll on wins a prize? Yes it sounds weird af but it’s an idea? If they are teenagers maybe buy them them some spray and rollon and say you’ve been the best student in the class so here’s a reward. Most teenagers get deodorant as a gift really. But yeah maybe It will work. Hope this helps

That depends on their family situation honestly, so no easy answer there…. Because it could be neglect, it could be cant afford, and a few other things. I would start by quietly asking the other teachers at your school if any of them have also noticed and if any of them have any idea about kids home situation, and go from there

Having had this situation many times, the information that a child is in need of proper hygiene should best come from the school nurse. He/she can ascertain if the problem is from lack of knowledge or resources and help in ways that you as the child’s teacher cannot.

As I personally did not experience this as a child, not that l know anyway, my perception was that the school nurse was the first port of call. And if the matter still persists then school liaison perhaps ? It is definitely a toughie. Cruel to be kind could be the answer. But l am sure the school nurse will prevail.

I would contact the family as it might be easier for the parents to talk to their child about hygiene. Or make it a day of talking about body changes and get permission from the principal so that the parents are aware of what their children are being taught.

I call our school nurse and give her what information I have about this child, then send the student to her. The nurse is the most appropriate person we have on staff to let a student know he or she is emitting orders which are causing us concern.

I’d probably try and address it discretely. You could try having a whole class discussion about hygiene and disguise it as a health lesson. Avoid singling the kid out in front of their peers but if this didn’t work you might need to pull them aside for a chat.

Really? If the problem is that bad the teacher won’t need to say anything. Instead make sure all your pupils know that any problem they can talk to you, that you want to help and you’re approachable. Suggest to them that they hang around at break and you’ll speak to them one to one.

The odour could be caused by several things, from disease, to diet and more. Discretion, would be a good thing to cultivate ; check with the parent/caretaker, first, as the child could be highly embarrassed, so to the parent/care provider. Hope this is of help to you

One of my math teachers at the first day of the term had brought a sticks of deodorant to class, and said since You guys usually have problems with body odor I have extra unused deodorant for you guys, if you aren’t able to get some or buy your own see me after class.

You don’t tell the child. You tell the parent. Some odors can come thru the pores of the skin. I normally don’t perspire, but on occasion that I have Indian cuisine I can detect the food “fragrance” slightly coming thru my pores. So if it is not that, but more of a “playground” odor he may not be bathing enough. I would consult the school nurse prior to speaking to the parent.

I had a conversation with a particular 4th grade student more than once: When you go to bed at night, don't wear your uniform pants in case you have an accident at night. Put on clean underwear every day. He complained that people said he stunk, never took my advice, and always smelled if urine.
You don’t tell the child that you don’t know their situation it would be embarrassing and they may withdraw from you. Requeste a meeting with a parent and be very gentle
Depending on the age. The very young, send a note home in a sealed envelope, With older kids, you take them aside and talk to them. Be open, maybe they live in the back of a car.

Pointing out for stinking may brought embarrassment for student. Instead directly pointing student ; you may generally talk about health hygiene. A teacher is a storyteller through curriculum that can be taken anywhere to any length for achieving good for students. There is nothing bad even bring into student's notice to bath with good quality soap. You can gift a deodorant to student with gifting some other things to his peers. There is nothing in it to weigh , the only thing matters ; the level of connection you have with your student. Simply appreciating neat students can encourage others to upkeep good hygiene. Students yearn for teachers attentions generally.
You DON’T! You pass it onto your line manager as a concern because it isn’t the child’s fault. The chances are that they are being neglected and the odour is the way that you can tell
I taught middle school for 8 years. This is pretty common. I go through the nurse who is better equipped to address the situation. Also counselors can approach them on a more personal basis.

I would tell the parents if they are in elementary school. If they are in middle or high school, I would talk to them privately - first by asking them if there is an underlying issue they are dealing with.

Tell them that you need to speak with them after class. Then ask them is everything ok at home. If they say yes than ask them why are they not washing up? Let them know that your asking this because you don't want them to get made fun of.

How old is the child. If they are from another country they may have different hygiene habits. I say that cause I’m from Greece and they don’t bathe every day like Americans. I would talk to the counselor. The child may have neglect issues. If the child is older just try to ask them if you could give them some advice.
Not easy but possible. Take the child a side and be gentle. Or, write a note and give it in an envelope. Not via an email. Suggest to change the diet to organic foods and no junk foods.
That is a problem for the school nurse or counselor. If the child is in sports or ohts ed, a coach could speak to him/her. Otherwise, I would suggest speaking to the parents.

I would consider talking to the parent & let them deal with it. A child may be very embarrassed or humiliated with that conversation, however well- intended. It may ruin the teacher- child relationship.

If its unbearable, and the smell affects the whole class i would talk to the parents. Any reasonable parent will thank you for bringing to their attention, but then again there are those who would take offence, but uknow it is what it is. 🤷‍♂️
You dont tell the child. You dont cause those scars bro. You talk to the person in charge of that child only. You do that in a non accusatory non judgemental manner!

Give a short talk about changes in bodies & hormones & how the older we get we have to take more frequent showers with soap or shower gel. Speak to parents if it doesn't help. Otherwise at some point classmates will comment & probably not in the best way.

Many years ago and several careers back, I taught first grade. I was faced with this issue. I had the school nurse talk to the child. I didn’t want to jeopardize our relationship by talking to him myself. It seemed to help.
if you are a teacher you wouldn't do that. You would talk to the parents. Obviously you aren't a teacher
You don't!!! Work with a school nurse or social worker. If you don't have such staff persons, you could make a phone call to the parent, but clear it with your superiors first.

In a polite & respectful tone, be blunt & inquisitive. Ask what their situation is; why they smell. If the reason for their stink is not their fault, don’t blame nor punish ’em & inform their parents/guardians.

A Hygiene situation should be addressed by the healthroom nurse or teacher to the parent or guardian Not The Child. If nothing is done by the Parent or Guardian Child Protective Services should be notified.
I would suggest that tell the child about hygiene instead and what happens if they don’t maintain hygiene. Then talk about odor.
you pull them away from a populated area and explain to them that they have a bad odor and find out how to fix the problem

That is something better brought up with the child's out- of- school caregiver, I think. Not only will they know how to best tackle the issue with the child, but they are ultimately responsible for the child's hygiene.
Probably don’t tell the child. Speak with his parent or get administration involved.
If it is a boy then tell a male teacher to talk to him. Also tell the male teacher you will do the same for him with a girl student in his class.
I suggest emailing the parent(s)/guardian(s) instead of putting the student in an embarrassing situation and yourself in a awkward scenario.
That’s not gonna help them. They might be sick. Maybe send them to school nurse.
I will not tell him or her; I will show them. I will purchase perfume, aloe vera soap and roll on.
Just tell the kid he stinks, and go to the back of the class,LOL
Don't damage the child, tell the parents “hey your kids stinks, fix it”.
